Background/Problem: The neural mechanisms by which the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) accomplishes cognitive control during conflict resolution remain unclear.
Method/Approach: Researchers used an audiovisual Stroop task with fNIRS and EEG measurements, and applied inhibitory TMS over the right DLPFC to test its causal role.
Result: The DLPFC suppresses distracting sensory input in auditory cortex and visual system during high-conflict situations, and an intact DLPFC enables conflict adaptation (Gratton effect).
Conclusion/Contribution: These findings provide causal evidence for the DLPFC's role in establishing conflict resolution across different sensory modalities in humans.
